title: Modelling in Energy Related Scenarios

author: Klemen Kenda, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: OK, so this presentation is on the modeling of the complex data space.
It's joint work that I have done with my colleagues and reversed Nick and Maya Koreans an it's a work done on the European project called Energy forecast.
So this project is, as the title says, about the forecasting energy consumption on energy demand in entities focused on public public buildings, public areas and similar.
So the motivation for this project is simply from the internal point of view of the stakeholders in this area that they want to save to save money in the end.
And this means on one hand it means saving energy with the consumption and on the other hand it means lowering the expenses for the energy.
For example, if you know exactly to tell how much energy you will need in the next day, you can buy this energy cheaper than if you don't know.
So all the penalties if you consume more or if you consume less.

Are quite big and external motivation is of course on different documents provided by the European Union, national documents or even local documents that demand from municipalities or other stakeholders to reduce energy consumption.
So the main achievement of this work that we had is that we have developed an environment, a platform that is able to do this stream mining.
This prediction of the energy consumption in streaming setting.
So basically we have created a platform that is able to join on one hand, sensor measurements, on the other hand some external data from the API's like weather predictions or weather data.
And the third thing could be some static properties that are needed for modeling these properties.
Or like is it working day today?
Is it working?
Cover and so on.

So this does not sound when I tell it like this, like a very complex task, but everybody who has tried to join this data together would know that there are many particular properties of this data that make this task difficult.
But later more about this.

The nice thing about our system is that it can work in offline mode, which we used for testing the models, and we can then almost seamlessly switch to the online mode so that it's working on the live streaming data.
It's basically done with one configuration file, so you define all your feature vectors in one file.

You define which model, and then the system is able to run by its own and as a collateral damage of all these work, some nice visualization to help the modeling software developed and we have looked at these models here at this particular use cases, the first use case is the epic spot market.
This is an European spot market where you can buy or sell the energy and so in this setting as I was.
Telling you before that you buy energy for one day ahead, it's really good to know what will be the prices of energy for the next day.
Then we have public buildings in Turin, Reggio Emilia in Italy and in Athens.
These are mostly University campus or some municipality buildings.
One use case is public lighting scenario.
It's based in the million municipality in Slovenia and the last use cases.
Terminal Station, also in Reggio Emilia in Italy, and the solution that we have made.
Based on the Q minor platform that is developed within our Department and it's a nice thing to check out if somebody doesn't.
Know it.

We develop the platform.

Then we develop the models we do some additional rechecking of the models, refining of the parameters.
Defining of the feature sets and in the end we have.

In today.

If it's a holiday day before holiday, so every feature that has some that may have influence on the shape of the consumption for upper.
Ocular day OK. Based on that we build full full feature vectors that we expected that would be relevant for us for all the different use cases and so the data here.

Like a sensor data.

So this data characteristic of this data is that it's usually coming online so we are getting sensor measurements as they arise.
They get to our system and they get recorded.
Here you have two things that can be a problem.
One problem is that this data that comes from the sensor has an arbitrary.
So you can get some measurements by the second you can get some by the hour or you can get some, maybe just each day.

So this is something that needs to be handled by the system and the other thing is that all of these sensor systems have some underlying platform behind, and this means that there is some lack with the measurements.

For example, for the public lighting we got measurements without dilay or 15 minutes and we got them in a bunch for some other data we got lack of six days, maybe some data needed to be somehow interacted by the user and we got it just once per day.
And this is something that needs to be handled.
When you are dealing with an online scenario, when you want things to happen.
With the stream processing engine, this is really important cause there you expect the data to be aligned by the time.
OK, the next type of data are weather forecasts.
These are particular in that case that this is not really a stream in a traditional sense because this weather forecasts get get updated.

So each hour they refine they run it through the model and you get new weather forecasts and this needs to be handled by the system and we have this static properties which are some sort of mixture between sensor and weather forecasts.
Becaused you can calculate this in advance, but you don't need them for the current time, but usually you need these values for the time when you are trying.
To predict something.
